articles.title: Tidal surges may flood low-lying areas in 15 coastal districts: Met office
articles.author: UNB
articles.summary: Low-lying areas in Bangladesh's coastal districts are likely to be inundated by tidal surges. The districts at risk include Satkhira, Khulna, Bagerhat, Jhalakathi, Pirojpur, Barishal, Barguna, Patuakhali, Bhola, Chandpur, Laxmipur, Noakhali and Feni. The depression over Gangetic West Bengal and adjoining northwest Bay and the Bangladesh coast moved west-northwestwards.

articles.title: Pakistan urges developed nations to fulfill $100 billion annual climate finance pledge
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Dr. Musadik Malik is the Federal Minister for Climate Change and Environmental Coordination. He represented Pakistan at the Heads of Delegation (HoD) retreat held in Shamakhi, Azerbaijan, on 25 July 2025. He called on developed nations to meet their pledged contributions to the $100 billion annual climate finance goal, a promise made under the 2015 Paris Agreement.

articles.title: Santa's in a sweat as Lapland's record heatwave hits 32C
articles.author: Jabed Ahmed
articles.summary: Lapland has been experiencing a persistent and intense heatwave for 15 days. The last time Lapland experienced a heatwave like this was in 1972. Forecasters predict the heat will ease this weekend and early next week. The weather has sparked fresh concerns about the pace of climate change in the Arctic.

articles.title: Islanders of Tuvalu Prepare first Mass Migration because of Sea Level Rise, as ICJ grants them Right to Sue
articles.author: Juan Cole
articles.summary: Half of Tuvalu's capital, Funafuti, is in danger of being submerged within 25 years due to climate change. Half of the island's 11,000 people will have to find somewhere else to live. Australia is offering residency visas to the people to study or work. Half the islanders have applied for this visa.

articles.title: Researchers abuzz about future of bees
articles.author: JOSHUA A. BICKEL
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise under climate change, scientists are trying to better understand the effects on managed and wild bees as they pollinate crops, gather nectar, make honey and reproduce. Bees are heat-tolerant, but as the climate warms, their ability to fend off disease and gather food might become harder. U.S. beekeepers lost 56% of their managed colonies this year.

articles.title: Sizzling summer
articles.author: Korea Herald
articles.summary: People are playing in the water at the 9th Seongbuk Cultural Vacation held at Seoul Soongduck Elementary School in northern Seoul on Saturday. The daily high is expected to reach 37 degrees Celsius in the capital city of Seoul, South Korea.

articles.title: Fertile fields or solar factory: a verdant land facing an industrial leap
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Farmers and fisherfolk of the picturesque and fertile Karedu in SPSR Nellore district fear that the government is taking steps to harm the area's agriculture and fishing industry. They are worried about the impact of the government's policies on their livelihoods.

articles.title: We are undergoing unprecedented loss of freshwater across the planet
articles.author: James Dinneen
articles.summary: There have been alarming declines in freshwater in many parts of the world between 2002 and 2024. Dry regions are expanding by more than 800,000 square kilometres per year. The team identified four areas where freshwater is being depleted at sites around the world, including the UK and France combined.

articles.title: Skagit County to hold public hearing on critical areas ordinance
articles.author: Emma Fletcher-Frazer
articles.summary: Skagit County Board of Commissioners will hold a public hearing on Monday for comment on the county's proposed changes to its critical areas ordinance. Critical areas include wetlands, frequently-flooded and geologically-hazardous areas, fish and wildlife habitat conservation areas, and areas that are key for the recharging of aquifers used for drinking water.

articles.title: Cities Tackle Rising Extreme Heat Threat
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: There was a heat wave in Europe in early July that killed more than 2,300 people. Most of them would have died if it wasn't for climate change. Since the Industrial Revolution, humans have been burning fossil fuels and filling the atmosphere with greenhouse gases, driving the global average temperature up 1.2C. Without major changes, 10% of all greenhouse gas emissions will come from cooling by 2050.

articles.title: Lapland heatwave sets record as temperatures soar 10C above average
articles.author: Iona Cleave
articles.summary: The heatwave in Lapland is expected to last until early next week. The highest temperature of the heatwave was 31.7C recorded at Ylitornio and Sodankylä earlier this week. There are also several dozen fast-spreading wildfires in the wilderness further north of Rovaniemi.

articles.title: US cities have seen an 80 percent increase in extreme heat streaks
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: There has been an 80 percent increase in extreme heat streaks across 247 analyzed US cities. Nashville and Raleigh have seen the most significant rise in heat streak frequency. Heat is the leading cause of weather-related deaths in the US, accounting for 2,325 deaths in 2023. A new heat wave is currently impacting 100 million Americans.

articles.title: Israel destroys massive aid shipments as Gaza faces worsening famine
articles.author: Al Bawaba
articles.summary: There are growing concerns about the well-being of people in Gaza. The situation in Gaza is of concern to many people around the world, including in Albaiba.       in Gaza are people in need of humanitarian aid. In Gaza, people are starving.

articles.title: ‘Vital to our existence': Local farmer talks importance of century farms
articles.summary: Humphrey Farms in Pender County, North Carolina has been run by the same family for at least 100 years. Gina Marasco took over for her dad 10 years ago. After Hurricane Florence, the farm was forced out of the hog business. Gina has expanded her workload from corn, livestock, lumber and long leaf pines to hosting events and renting Airbnbs.

articles.title: The Dry Earth Dilemma: The Interplay Between Drought and Rising Sea Levels
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: There is a significant reduction in available freshwater, according to a recent study. The researchers used data from a suite of four NASA satellites to analyze changes in terrestrial water storage over the past 22 years. The study found that every large land mass, except for Greenland and Antarctica, has experienced unprecedented drying since 2002.

articles.title: DA ensures stable food supply
articles.author: Christine Boton
articles.summary: There was over P1.1 billion in damage to agriculture caused by tropical cyclones and the southwest monsoon. The Department of Agriculture has enough food supply for more than 12 days' worth of national requirements. Occidental Mindoro accounted for the highest amount of damage, followed by Palawan with P45 million and North Cotabato with P58 million. Bataan and Negros Occidental have declared a state of calamity.

articles.title: Downpour in Kerala, IMD issues 'red alert' in 3 districts
articles.summary: Heavy rains since Friday night have caused widespread damage across several parts of Kerala. IMD has upgraded rain alert status in Ernakulam, Idukki, and Thrissur districts from 'orange' to 'red'. It also issued an 'orange alert' for Pathanamthitta, Kottayam, Palakkad, Malappuram, Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod districts. The IMD said rains are likely to persist over the next five days, accompanied by strong winds.

articles.title: It's not your imagination: Winnipeg summers are smokier than they used to be
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: There's been more smoke in Winnipeg's air in recent summers. It's not just your smoke.    Winnipeg's air has been smoky in the summers recently. It may be due to smoky summers in Winnipeg, not just smoke in the air.

articles.title: Record-breaking heat scorches regions across four continents as marine heatwave intensifies
articles.author: Saudi Gazette
articles.summary: Scorching heat swept across Europe, Asia, the Middle East and North America this week. It broke temperature records and triggered warnings from meteorologists that extreme conditions are possible. It is expected to get hotter in the coming days. It's expected to reach the mid-90s in some parts of Europe.

articles.title: Mountain roads and coal mines cut grizzly bears off from habitat, study finds
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Grizzly bears have to change their movements across the Canadian Rockies to avoid human development like coal mines, highways, large reservoirs and towns, according to a new study.       .   "Grizzy bears are avoiding human development.

articles.title: Study reveals fundamental shift in Antarctic food chain base
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: A global study involving Australian scientists has uncovered dramatic shifts at the base of the Antarctic food web. Experts warn of a fundamental reorganization of life in the region. The study documents an ecological system change in the southern polar ocean caused by climate change and could influence climate through a feedback mechanism.

articles.title: The oceans are overheating—and scientists say a climate tipping point may be here
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: In 2023, the world's oceans experienced the most intense and widespread marine heatwaves ever recorded, with some areas experiencing some of the hottest temperatures ever recorded. Some areas experienced extreme heatwaves in the oceans. Some places had extreme heat waves in the whole oceans.

articles.title: Predicting genomic adaptation to climate change in teak, a valuable tropical tree species
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Climate change is affecting forest ecosystems through rising temperatures, altered precipitation patterns and increased frequency of extreme weather events. Tropical forests are particularly vulnerable to these changes. The forestry sector is expected to experience severe effects due to the long-lived and long-lasting effects of climate change.
